PROFESSOR: OK, I'm going
to talk about 3J, 6J,
and Wigner-Eckhart theorem. This is a topic that--

I've always not liked
using 3Js and 6Js. Because I felt that for
most of the problems

that I wanted to
work on, I could derive all of the angular
momentum transformations

using raising and lowering
operators and orthogonality and doing some very
elaborate algebra.

And for some reason,
I thought that was virtuous and wonderful. And I didn't want to have to
refer to these transformations.

They are very convenient,
especially now that you can ask computers to
do almost everything that I once

did by hand. And so let's talk about
transformations between bases

sets and what are you going to
do with these transformations between bases sets.

So as an example, I'm going
to use one problem that I've

Zeeman Hamiltonians for atoms.

we encounter two
different bases sets. Where we encounter
the coupled bases set and the uncoupled bases set.

And so the coupled

And the uncoupled is L ML
S MS. And these two bases

sets have labels here. This corresponds to an
eigenvalue of L squared,

J squared, of JZ. And so these are
the quantum numbers

the basis functions. One of the useful
things about this

is that whenever an operator is

S squared, J squared, or JZ,

minus, we know what happens.

And so when we have operators

I probably ought to

orbit operator like this.

We know this because-- we know this for

vector with respect

So we know that this thing

as well.

This thing, though, if

spin-orbit Hamiltonian is not

Because this is a

We can't write.

This is not 0. And all of the components--
all of the components of J

here, all the components. So it's telling you

The uncoupled basis

for dealing with the
spin-orbit orbit Hamiltonian. So if it's a good
idea, then there

ought to be a way of
rewriting the spin-orbit orbit Hamiltonian so that

And this is a trick that

coupled to make a third.

The coupled basis is
always a good basis. And most operators that
you're going to encounter

are dot products between
two angular momenta. And so you always want to choose
a basis that makes that dot
product really trivial. And this is the way it's done. So we have L is equal to J--

J is equal to L plus

And so J squared is L
squared plus S squared plus two L dot S. And so

as L dot S is equal
to one half, J

squared minus L squared
minus S squared.

So here is an operator
that we'd like to look at to

And here are three operators. And these are three
operators which are diagonal in the
coupled basis and not

in the uncoupled basis. We have trouble with this
in the uncoupled basis.

These two are just fine. But this is not fine. So we can evaluate
matrix element

LSJ MJ spin-orbit.

LSJ MJ is going to be equal to
zeta over 2 times JMJ plus 1,

set that makes evaluation of

And that's the answer. However, sometimes
you have a problem because you have
another operator

that you have to deal with,

Well, but you want to

I'm going to write

uncoupled basis sets.

And so you want to
end up with L, ML, S,

MS. And so to do that,

This is something we want. OK, and now, in doing

sub S, which are the

do a transformation

either M sub L or M sub S.

So we're going to
do a sum over--

we're going to do a sum
here, which is a sum over,

let's say M sub S. And it

And we can rewrite M sub L

And so we're just doing the sum. And this would be, in the case
that L is greater than or equal

to S. If S is

L from minus L to plus L.

So we can formally
write a transformation, either in the forward direction
going from coupled to uncoupled
or from uncoupled to coupled. Now, these are angular momenta.

involuntary, rather than

momenta and did something, you would be able to derive
general transformations

Because they don't care whether

And they're called
3J coefficients. And they're various forms.

They're called
Gordon coefficients, they're called Wigner-- no they're not.

They're called vector
coupling coefficients. But the 3J is the

These are tabulated. OK, so one of the

cyclic permutations-- I'm doing this from memory

If you do cyclic permutations

fantastic symmetry. These vector coupling
coefficients,

And the tables can be small

J coefficients.

They're used always for
going between a coupled and an uncoupled basis set.

It's the most common

angular momenta.

And so it's useful to
practice with three Js.

And another path would

plus I. In other words,

et where this one is diagonal.
